speaker: Mr Sullivan
theText: Okay. The committee chairman covered the youth enrolment procedure, where we have recadvertising processes, material into the schools and visits to the schools-to encourage youth enrolments. That is probably going to cost more and be less effective than inviting the institutions to ensure that eligible students are enrolled. The bottom line here is this: we have compulsory enrolment with the object of compulsory voting in this country. If we are going to compel citizens in this regard then the corollary is that the government is compelled to ensure that citizens can perform that compulsory act without undue difficulty. There are a couple of other issues that have been raised, but I want to go to this ludicrous suggestion that we should consider the introduction of optional preferential voting. I have had some experience of this. I was elected to the Queensland parliament under compulsory preferential voting and unelected from the Queensland parliament under the process of optional preferential voting. But it is my view that optional preferential voting is the worse of all possible voting systems, with the possible exception of plurality, which we know as ‘first past the post’. What we know today as compulsory or full preferential voting was invented in Australia, and internationally it is known as the ‘Australian ballot.’ The purpose of the Australian ballot was to ensure that a person elected enjoyed the preferential support of greater than 50 per cent of electors. On the one voting occasion it duplicates the run-off system in vogue in many parts of the world. As an elected member of this parliament I take great comfort from the fact that I have the demonstrated support of more than 50 per cent of the voters of Longman, that more people preferred me rather than my opponent as their representative. By contrast, an examination of the 2001 Queensland state election, won by a landslide by Premier Beattie, shows that 16 or 17 of the government MPs did not have that demonstrated support. After the distribution of preferences that had been allocated by voters, the total votes for those MPs was fewer than 50 per cent of the formal votes cast in their electorates. In effect, by exhausting their votes, voters are saying to the successful candidate that more than half of them prefer the other main candidate or that nobody represents them. This is a distortion. Optional preferential voting distorts the proposition that we should be electing parliamentarians and governments that enjoy majority support of electors. It certainly does not distort it to the degree that plurality or first past the post does. But evidence in my home state shows that, in each election since the introduction of optional preferential voting, an increasing number of voters are opting to ‘plump’ or to simply indicate a first preference, and in that regard optional preferential voting is slowly morphing, inevitably, into first-past-the-post voting. I do not see any large clamouring for first-past-the-post voting. In the few remaining moments allocated to me, I wish to say something about the use of technology in relation to our electoral system. I do not want to sound like I am an iconoclast, but I think it is time-sometime this century, preferably sooner-that we start to make greater use of online provisions in people’s dealings with the AEC. I undertake some online banking with one of Australia’s major banks and I am happy that my money is secure via that process because of the account number, password, secret questions and SMS provisions. I think these provisions are an excellent way of looking towards introducing online transactions, at least in a small way initially and later on to a full online voting system. the conduct of the 2007 federal election and matters related thereto is important. I want to begin by expressing my admiration for my colleague the honourable member for Banks and his judicious chairing of this committee. This excellent, extensive and, some people would say, exhaustive report on electoral matters which we are now considering is a reflection of his and the government’s leadership on this particular issue. I want to thank all other members of the committee, including the member for Longman, who just spoke, and of course the committee secretariat for their expertise and dedication in facilitating our work in so many different ways. Australia’s electoral system is virtuous, particularly when compared with systems operating in many other countries, including our great democratic ally, the United States. The US has a system of redistricting, organised by the congress, which would never be tolerated in Australia, but it leads to all kinds of distortions, even in their great democratic system. I believe we have one of the fairest, most transparent and most efficient electoral systems. The member for Longman pointed out the vacuous, non-empirical nature of the minority response to this report, and I do not want to dignify it by examining its non-evidence based prejudices. Instead, I focus on the combination in Australia of bicameralism, compulsory voting, preferential voting for the House of Representatives and proportional representation in the Senate, a system which is unique in the world. It combines the best of British Westminster heritage with the best of American federal representation, with added features of our own. Compulsory voting encourages civic participation and means that all Australians share the responsibility for choosing their government. The member for Longman pointed out the pitfalls of adopting optional preferential voting. Single member seats in the House of Representatives ensure that we usually have stable majority governments. PrefMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Committees

speaker: Mr Danby (Melbourne Ports) (12.39 Pm)
theText: The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters Report onerential voting gives all voters the ability to influence the results of their electorate. Proportional representation in the Senate gives minority parties a voice without undermining stable government. All Australians should take pride in our electoral system. This great report will reverse the damage that the previous government did to the integrity, openness and fairness of our electoral system with its unnecessary, partisan, short-sighted and foolish changes to the Electoral Act before the last federal election-changes to the Electoral Act that had never been made before any other election because they were not needed. The system was fair and the changes at the last federal election were a political manoeuvre designed to try and give them a little extra edge when they thought they were going to lose it. The changes were based on an assertion which was completely and demonstrably false that there was significant false enrolment or other electoral fraud which made it necessary to bring in measures to make it more difficult for Australians to enrol to vote. Everyone knew this was a false assertion. I knew it, the Australian Electoral Commission knew it, respected election analysts such as Professors Brian Costa and Malcolm Mackerras knew it, and I am pretty sure the former government knew it. It was a cynical falsehood put out by the former government to provide a fig leaf of justification for their self-interested manipulation of the electoral system for their partisan advantage. Let me go through again, like a parrot, the history of so called Australian electoral fraud. In the period 1990 to 2001, there were six electoral events, including a referendum, with 12 million votes cast at each of them. Altogether, 72 million votes were cast during this period. In that period the Australian Electoral Commission showed that there were 72 proven cases of electoral fraud-one case per million votes cast. That was the basis on which 100,000 Australians were disenfranchised at the last election by these terrible changes to the Electoral Act-a completely bodgie manoeuvre. The report we are debating today confirms and documents the falsity of that claim and documents the harmful effects of the changes that the Howard government made. The report quotes the AEC’s submission: It can be clearly stated in relation to false identities that there has never been any evidence of widespread or organised electoral fraud in Australia. The report shows that the Howard government changes had the effect of disenfranchising tens of thousands of Australian citizens at the 2007 election, which is exactly what I predicted and other members of the then opposition said would happen when these changes were debated in the House. More than 27,000 provisional voters were rejected because they did not comply with the new tightened requirements. The number of formal provisional votes fell from 112,000 in 2004 to 42,000 in 2007. This decrease was entirely due to the changes made by the previous government. On the basis of past experience, we believe at least 50,000 people would have been enrolled in the traditional seven-day period of grace after the calling of an election, but they were prevented from doing so. Many more were disenfranchised by being taken off the rolls by the AEC when they changed address and then were deterred from re-enrolling by the more onerous enrolment procedures. In 2004, 77,000 people were added to the rolls after the close of the rolls, because they had been incorrectly removed. In 2007 only 1,400 were able to do so. My estimate is that 100,000 Australians were thus prevented from enrolling or voting by the changes made by the previous government, about 700 per federal electorate. I believe the majority, possibly quite a large majority, of those disenfranchised people came from social groups more likely to vote Labor: first-time voters, new citizens, Indigenous Australians, people with poor or low literacy skills, itinerant workers and homeless people. That was, of course, the belief of the former government which led them to the lengths of disenfranchising their fellow Australians. It might be thought that 700 votes per federal electorate, each constituency with between 90,000 and 100,000 voters, is not a significant proportion. Need we be reminded, however, that in 2007 the honourable member for McEwen was elected by a margin of 12 votes, the honourable member for Bowman by 64 votes, the honourable member for Swan by 164 votes and the honourable member for Dickson by 217 votes. I believe that all four of these members won their seats only because of the deliberate disenfranchisement of likely Labor voters by the former government. As it turned out that was not enough to save the previous government from defeat but if the election had been closer it might have been-and that was the very plan. I might say that I find it completely incomprehensible that newspapers like the Courier Mail focus on the undemocratic role of donations and lobbying in Queensland but they are not willing to look at the bodgie results produced by the electoral changes at the last federal election in their state, particularly in two seats in their state. The former government liked to talk about electoral fraud. As this report documents, it was a bogus claim. But if there was ever a clear case of electoral fraud in Australia, if there was ever a case of Australian voters been defrauded of their right to vote, cynically and deliberately, it was the changes made to the electoral laws by the previous government. The report recommends that the changes made to the Electoral Act by the previous government MAIN COMMITTEE should be reversed. That is the policy we took to the last election and that is the policy to which we remain committed. The former Special Minister for State, Senator Faulkner, set in train a process of consultation leading up to the green paper setting out a timetable for legislation. The current minister, Senator Ludwig, is continuing with that process. We have seen the first stage of the government’s response to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment (Political Donations and Other Measures) Bill 2009, which is currently, again, before the Senate. Now, again, we have this brouhaha in Queensland about lobbyists and donations et cetera, but it is the Liberal Party, the coalition in the Senate, that has already blocked changes that would make donations to political parties more open and transparent, and we hear nothing from the Courier Mail. I ask the editorial staff of the Courier Mail, will you please read the debates in parliament about the donations bill? Would you please pay attention to what is actually happening in this area? The government remains committed to reversing the Howard government’s unfair and unnecessary changes to the Electoral Act, which closed the rolls immediately after the issuing of the writs and, as I repeatedly pointed out, which particularly affects younger people-deliberately so-and which required photo ID for people wishing to enrol, change their enrolment details or cast a provisional vote. The thing that I find the most outrageous and egregious about these changes is that the previous government was elected at all elections between 1996 and 2001 on the previous system. They did not claim that it was undemocratic then. The coalition were quite properly elected. Yet they invalidated the very system under which they were elected three times to try and benefit themselves at the 2007 election. All of those provisional voters who were allowed to vote in 1996, 1998 and 2001 were disenfranchised in 2007. It really is an anti-democratic outrage. The evidence set out in this report reinforces the argument that I and many others made for the repeal of those changes. I welcome the government’s continuing commitment to do this and I look forward to that commitment being translated into legislation as soon as possible. I am going to take up my full amount of time by re-emphasising some of the other figures on the so-called ‘integrity of the roll’ issue. Let me go through some of the figures that were revealed to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters by the Electoral Commissioner. There were 17,000 apparent multiple votes at the 2001 election, for instance; 15,000 of those, or 88 per cent, were an indication from responses that no further action was required. These were tracked down, and they did not need to be pursued. There were 920 people whom the AEC got no responses from. Letters were undelivered or people were not able to be found. So, at the 2001 election the AEC narrowed this down to a further 896 examples of what was thought to be multiple voting. People like the member for Sturt have railed about the integrity of the electoral roll at previous elections. Of those 896 multiple voters, 739, or 82 per cent, were elderly people who completely innocently, as a matter of confusion or because of poor comprehension, voted twice-at a mobile polling booth and then on the day. We know the kind of circumstances where this can happen without any kind of electoral fraud or malevolence by these elderly voters. This accounted for 82 per cent of the cases of multiple voting at the 2001 election, and it was roughly the same proportion at the 2004 and 2007 elections. There were only 138 cases referred to the AFP, of which five were accepted for investigation. So out of 13.6 million Australian voters we have only five proven cases of electoral fraud, which the DPP decided, at the 2001 election. We have 1.2 million Australians unenrolled. That is a much more serious issue. At the last election 90-plus per cent of Australians voted, but the proportion is dropping over the years. As members of parliament all know, the AEC is almost trained to take people off the electoral roll. But we need to have a more modern process where we use all kinds of devices, such as the internet, particularly with young people, so they are able to send their re-enrolment details back in. People do not fill out handwritten snail mail these days and send it back to the extent that old-timers like the people sitting in this room do. We have to make some kind of provision new, savvy Electoral Commissioner-and try some of these electronic means of increasing enrolment. In a compulsory voting system, we have a duty and a responsibility to ensure that the franchise is as wide as possible-not to restrict it, not to exclude voters because of possible perceptions of how they might vote at a federal election, and certainly not to do it in this blatantly bodgie kind of way where we used the system at three elections and then changed it at the last election. I am very, very pleased with this excellent, extensive, exhaustive report that the member for Banks has led the charge on. I think one of the great effects of this new government being elected will be to widen the democratic franchise to increase democratic prospects in Australia, I am very proud to add my name to support it and its recommendations. Debate (on motion by Mr Hawke) adjourned. Main Committee adjourned at 12.54 pm MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Committees

speaker: For The Changing Nature Of Communications. A Very Good Way Would Be To Follow The Lead Of Mr Killesteyn
theText: theResources, Energy and Tourism: Intergovernmental Agreements (Question Nos 746 and 747) Mr Andrews asked the Minister for Resources and Energy and the Minister for Tourism, in writing, on 13 May 2009: In respect of any intergovernmental agreements that exist in the Minister’s portfolio: (a) how many exist; (b) what are their (i) names, and (ii) objectives and purposes; (c) what are the names of the parties to each; and (d) will the Minister provide a copy of each; if not, why not. Mr Martin Ferguson-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: Refer to the COAG website http://www.coag.gov.au/ and the DFAT website http://www.dfat.gov.au/treaties/ for centrally coordinated intergovernmental agreements. With respect to the Resources, Energy and Tourism (RET) portfolio: (a) One hundred and thirty five intergovernmental agreements exist in the RET portfolio. (b) (i) refer to Attachment A, (ii) refer to Attachment A. (c) refer to Attachment A. (d) Attachment A provides a listing of all existing intergovernmental agreements in the RET Portfolio. I am not prepared to authorise the commitment of resources required to provide the requested copy of each agreement. However, if after review of Attachment A, the Honourable Member wishes to nominate specific Agreements of interest, these can be made available on request, unless otherwise indicated at Attachment A. I have also provided a link where the Agreement is available online. Attachment A Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism Name of Agreement Objective and Purpose Names of the Parties Will the Minister provide a copy? Innovation, Industry, Science and Research: Intergovernmental Agreements (Question No. 751) Mr Andrews asked the Minister representing the Minister for Innovation, Industry, Science and Research, in writing, on 13 May 2009: In respect of any intergovernmental agreements that exist in the Minister’s portfolio: (a) how many exist; (b) what are their (i) names, and (ii) objectives and purposes; (c) what are the names of the parties to each; and (d) will the Minister provide a copy of each; if not, why not. to the honourable member’s question: I refer to the Honourable Member to the COAG and DFAT websites, which list the intergovernmental agreements signed at COAG meetings and the treaties to which Australia is a signatory respectively. Details of additional agreements are provided in the table below and copies attached as appropriate: Notes: 1. Intergovernmental agreements between the Commonwealth of Australia and other governments and multilateral intergovernmental institutions, in which ANSTO has an interest are part of the Department of Foreign Affairs’ Treaties Database and the science and technology agreements facilitated by the Department of Innovation, Industry, Science and Research. tional Atomic Energy Agency, the Forum for Nuclear Cooperation in Asia and the Nuclear Energy Agency. In addition, many, Argentina and France. However, the precise detail requested in the question is not readily available and would be resource intensive to provide. 2. Pursuant to CSIRO’s enabling legislation (Science and Industry Research Act 1949 (SIR Act) (Cth)), CSIRO is established as a body corporate and is legally separate from the Commonwealth. As a Commonwealth Authority governed by the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, CSIRO is also financially separate from the Commonwealth. In this regard, CSIRO differs from government departments and agencies governed by the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 and has separate powers and obligations from FMA Act bodies. CSIRO is not empowered under the SIR Act to enter into ‘intergovernmental agreements’ and is unable to bind the Commonwealth legally or financially by entering into international agreements on behalf of the Commonwealth.

National Partnership Agreement on the Nation Building and Jobs Plan (Question No. 753) Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Housing, in writing, on 14 May 2009 In respect of the National Partnership Agreement (NPA) on Stage1 (for new housing construction) of the Nation Building and Jobs Plan: (1) On what date did the (a) New South Wales, (b) Victorian, (c) Queensland, (d) South Australian, (e) Tasmanian, (f) Australian Capital Territory, and (g) Northern Territory, Government provide a funding proposal to the Australian Government. (2) Were any funding proposals received after 15 March 2009; if so, (a) from which State and Territory government/s, and (b) were reasons provided for not meeting the deadline; if so, what were they. (3) On what date did the Australian Government approve the proposal submitted by (1) (a) to (g). (4) Were any funding approvals given after 1 April 2009; if so, (a) to what State and Territory government/s, and (b) what reasons were provided to each State and Territory government by the Australian Government for the delay. (5) To 14 May 2009, what sum of funding has been allocated to (1) (a) to (g). Ms Plibersek-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1), (2), (3) and (5) Jurisdiction Date proposal Date of decision(s) Funding allocated to received 14 May 2009 New South Wales2 March 2009 26 March 2009 $13,040,000 Victoria4 March 2009 31 March 2009 $9,916,000 Queensland 3 March 2009 31 March 2009 and $8,010,000 9 April 2009 Western Australia 27 February 2009 31 March 2009 $4,049,000 South Australia 13 March 2009 31 March 2009 $1,499,000 Tasmania 27 February 2009 26 March 2009 $933,000 Australian Capital Territory 2 March 2009 26 March 2009 $645,000 Northern Territory 13 March 2009 31 March 2009 $217,000 (4) The Minister requested that the Queensland Government provide more detail on their proposal. The revised proposal was then received on 8 April and the Minister approved that proposal on 9 April. Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act (Question No. 754) Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 14 May 2009: Does section 16 of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1995 require him to (a) prepare a report on the operation of that Act for each financial year, and (b) table it in Parliament; if so, has this report been prepared for the 2006-07 and 200708 financial years, and will he table them by 30 June 2009; if not, why not, and when will he table them. Section 16 of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1995 (the Act) requires that the Minister report to Parliament ‘as soon as practicable’ after 30 June each year on the operation of the Act. There is no set date by which the report must be tabled. The 2006-07 report was tabled out of session on 8 July 2009. Taree Airport (Question No. 756) Mr Oakeshott asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 14 May 2009: For the period 1 January 1994 to 14 May 2009, what is the full record of communications and correspondence held by his department and his office relating to Taree Airport. The Department holds letters and/or notes of conversations relating to the planning and funding of Taree Airport. National Partnership Agreement on Social Housing (Question No. 758) Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Housing, in writing, on 25 May 2009: In respect of the Social Housing Growth Funds and the National Partnership Agreement on Social Housing
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Albanese
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Albanese
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Which State and Territory governments submitted proposals to the Australian Government before 2 March 2009 for funding for the 2008-09 financial year. (2) Were any proposals submitted after 2 March 2009; if so, by which State and Territory government/s. (3) What was the total combined monetary value of all proposals received. (4) Has the Australian Government entered into any bilateral agreements with any State or Territory government in respect of any proposal submitted in part (1); if so, with which State and Territory government/s. (5) Has the Australian Government made any payment to a State or Territory government in respect of any bilateral agreement; if so, what sum was paid, and to which State or Territory government/s. Ms Plibersek-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Seven States and Territories submitted draft or final proposals for the 2008-09 financial year on or before 2 March 2009. (2) The Northern Territory submitted its proposal on 5 March 2009. Final proposals were received from New South Wales on 20 March 2009, Western Australia on 10 March 2009 and South Australia on 12 March 2009. (3) The combined monetary value of the proposals received was $303,197,099. This is an estimate as some States and Territories provided the total cost of projects that will be undertaken over the two years and for these the costs were evenly divided over the two years. (4) The Australian Government has entered into bilateral agreements with all States and Territories in respect of their 200809 proposals. (5) As at 7 June 2009 the Australian Government had paid the following amounts: New South Wales $65.201 million; Victoria $49.576 million; Queensland $40.048 million. Western Australia $20.244 million; South Australia $14.990 million; Tasmania $4.662 million; The Australian Capital Territory $3.221 million; and The Northern Territory $2.058 million. National Partnership Remote Indigenous Housing (Question No. 760) Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 25 May 2009: In respect of the National Partnership Agreement on Remote Indigenous Housing (1) Do any State and Territory governments not yet have agreed implementation plans in place; if so, which State and Territory government/s, and what are the reasons for the delays in completing such plans. (2) Is Australian Government funding under this agreement for the 2009-10 financial year $432.733 million; if not, what is the total sum of funding. (3) What share of funding in part (2) will each State government and the Northern Territory government receive. Ms Macklin-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) All States and the Northern Territory have agreed the implementation plans for the National Partnership on Remote Indigenous Housing. (2) The amount notionally allocated by the Australian Government to the States and the Northern Territory under the National Partnership on Remote Indigenous Housing for 2009-10 is $432.732 million. (3) The amount notionally allocated for each State and the Northern Territory under the National Partnership on Remote Indigenous Housing for 2009-10 is set out below: State Funding $m New South Wales 63.188 Queensland 69.220 Victoria 4.519 Western Australia 105.834 South Australia 52.696 Tasmania 4.892 Northern Territory 132.383 Plastics Recycling (Question No. 764) Mr Robert asked the Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts, in writing, on 26 May 2009: (1) Where in Australia can (a) Low Density Polyethylene Plastics Identification Code (PIC) 4, (b) Polypropylene PIC 5, and (c) Polystyrene PIC 6, be recycled. (2) Where in Australia can (a) Polyethylene Teraphthalate PIC 1, (b) High Density Polyethylene PIC 2, and (c) Polyvinyl Chloride or Vinyl PIC 3, be recycled. (3) If PICs 4, 5 and 6 cannot be recycled, when will they be phased out. (1) Plastics4 (Low Density Polyethylene) and 5 (Polypropylene) are collected for recycling by local government kerbside systems in most metropolitan and some regional areas across Australia. They are also accepted by some recycling depots and transfer stations. Their inclusion in kerbside recycling is a matter for local government who will generally consider the costs, benefits and practicalities of collecting these plastics in their region. Plastics4 and 5 are processed at facilities across Australia. Where plastic with a Plastics Identification Code of 6 (polystyrene) are available in commercially viable quantities, services are available for their collection and recycling. Polystyrene is also collected for recycling by some local government kerbside systems. While the majority of polystyrene collected for recycling is exported for processing, there is a plant in Mildura in Victoria which utilises recycled polystyrene to produce products including posts, bollards and stakes. (2) Plastics with a Plastics Identification Code of 1, 2 and 3 are collected for recycling by most local government kerbside systems, recycling depots and transfer stations. Processing facilities for these plastics are located across Australia. (3) Plastics with a Plastics Identification Code of 4, 5 and 6 can be recycled. Queensland: Flying Foxes (Question No. 767) Mr Bruce Scott asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 1 June 2009: Is the Government intending to implement a damage mitigation program to control the population of flying foxes, which are having a significant environmental and economic impact on growers of orchards and crops across Queensland (QLD); if so, when will this program begin; and if not, will he consider implementing such a program to assist QLD food producers given the QLD Government has ceased providing Damage Mitigation Permits to control the flying fox population. Ms Burke-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: The Government supports the effective management of flying fox populations and their impact through contributions to research. Fruit growing levypayers may wish to propose that Horticulture Australia Limited (HAL) sponsor research into flying foxes and non-lethal control measures. HAL makes an annual industry call for proposals around September each year that address specific industry priorities. HAL funds priority research on behalf of 26 statutory levy-paying horticultural industries and other industries and organisations that make voluntary contributions (including the stonefruit and apple/pear bodies). The government matches, on a dollar for dollar basis, industry contributions (both statutory and voluntary) paid to HAL for research up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of the industry. The on-farm agricultural production and native animal management aspects relating to flying foxes are state and territory responsibilities and associated mainly with state/territory legislation. Agencies in those jurisdictions are working with affected fruit growers to manage the extent of damage on their orchards and crops. Funding assistance through state governments is available to growers for non-lethal methods to control flying fox damage to their orchards, such as netting. In Queensland the Primary Industry Productivity Enhancement Scheme makes available low interest loads of up to $500,000, which can be repaid over a 20 year period, to establish control methods. In NSW the Special Conservation Scheme makes available loans for exclusion netting. These loans are for up to fifteen years and for 90% of the net cost of the netting up to a maximum of $150,000. Biodiversity Adjustment Scheme (Question No. 768) Mr Tuckey asked the Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts, in writing, on 1 June 2009: In respect of the Biodiversity Adjustment Scheme(1) What sum of funding under this scheme has been made available to Western Australia, and for what purpose was it expended. (2) Does or did Western Australia retain any surplus from this funding; if so, what was the sum of the surplus.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Garrett
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) Does any agreement exist between the Commonwealth and the States for surplus funds to be transferred within a State to be used for other purposes; if so, did the Western Australian Government use any surplus funding under the scheme on other projects; if so, what are the details. Biodiversity Adjustment Scheme is a Western Australia State initiative. It is administered by the Western Australia Department of Environment and Conservation. The Australian Government does not participate in this activity. No agreement exists between the Commonwealth and the State for the Biodiversity Adjustment Scheme HMAS Sydney II (Question No. 770) Mr Baldwin asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 2 June 2009: (1) How many (a) photographic images, and (b) minutes of video footage, were taken as part of the discovery and investigation into the wreck of the HMAS Sydney (II). (2) Will more photographic images be released to the public; if so, (a) how many, (b) when, and (c) will they be able to be used free of copyright restrictions; if not, why not. (3) Will more video footage be released to the public; if so, (a) howmuch, (b) when, and (c) will it be able to be used free of copyright restrictions; if not, why not. tion: (1) (a) 1139 photos were taken of HMAS Sydney II and its wreck site. 291 photos were taken of HSK Kormoran and its wreck site. (b) As part of the discovery and investigation, approximately 3,600 minutes (60 hours) were taken of HMAS Sydney II and HSK Kormoran. (2) (a) (b) and (3) The HMAS Sydney II Commission of Inquiry has requested no further release of photographic images or video footage until the Inquiry has had time to consider all the material and evidence placed before it. (c) The Finding Sydney Foundation is currently winding up its operation, having completed its objectives by locating HMAS Sydney II and HSK Kormoran and setting up a Virtual Memorial. The Finding Sydney Foundation is in discussions with an appropriate national institution to ensure that copyright for all the material, including photographs and video imagery, is assigned to an appropriate national institution, including the provision of all material to that institution. Roads: Gocup Road (Question No. 771) Mrs Hull asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 3 June 2009: (1) Who was responsible in the NSW Government for submitting the funding application to the Australian Government to upgrade Gocup Road between Gundagai and Tumut. (2) Can he advise who was involved in the formulation of the application; if so, who. (3) Did the application comply with funding guidelines of the Federal Government Funding Authority. (4) What sum of funding was requested in the application. (5) On what date did applications (a) open, and (b) close. (6) Was the application lodged by the close date. (7) To whom was the application addressed. (8) Was he aware of the application; if not, why not. (9) Was the Federal Member for Eden Monaro advised of the application; if so, by whom and when. (1) and (2) This is a matter for the NSW Government. (3) N/A. The proposal was not submitted to any particular program. There was no request for applications from the Australian Government. (4) to (8) Refer to (3) (9) This is a matter for the Member for Eden Monaro.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Garrett
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Combet
theText: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s ques
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Albanese
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Australian Training and Support Team East Timor (Question No. 772) Mr Lindsay asked the Minister for Defence Personnel, Materiel and Science, in writing, on 4 June 2009: (1) Is he aware of the ongoing campaign for formal public recognition of the Warlike Service (WLS) of the Australian Training and Support Team East Timor (ATST-EM). (2) Did the Government direct the Department of Defence to release a DEFGRAM on 26 March 2009 announcing the recognition of WLS for the ATST-EM; if so, who was the responsible Minister or Parliamentary Secretary. (3) What protocols, processes or legal requirements must be fulfilled to have the WLS of the ATSTEM publicly recognised. (4) Will he publicly announce recognition of WLS for ATST-EM veterans who served on active service in East Timor; if not, why not. (5) Does the award of a War Service Pension (WSP) to qualifying persons depend upon the formal public recognition of active WLS. (6) Is he aware that members of the ATST-EM who have qualified for a WSP, are having their applications denied due to a lack of public recognition of active service in East Timor; if not, why not. (7) Did the Deputy Chief of Army, at any stage, order ATST-EM members to return their United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor (UNTAET) medals; if so, why. (8) Have ATST-EM members been retrospectively awarded the UNTAET medal; if not, why not. (1) Yes. (2) No. (3) There are no protocols, processes or legal requirements that must be fulfilled to have the WLS of the ATST-EM publicly recognised. (4) No decision has been made to publicly announce recognition of WLS for ATST-EM veterans who served on active service in East Timor. (5) and (6) There is no requirement for public recognition to qualify for the award of the War Service Pension. Personnel wishing to access veterans’ entitlements associated with their service in ATST-EM can do so once Department of Veterans’ Affairs has confirmed their service with Defence. (7) I am advised that the Army understands that in 2001 an investigation was commissioned by the then Commander of the Australian Contingent – East Timor into how the Australian Training Support Team– East Timor received the UNTAET medal, as they were not assigned to the United Nations. In 2003, it is further understood that a direction was issued that the medals had been issued in error and that they be withdrawn. Action was initiated by the Army to comply with this direction. (8) The UNTAET Medal can only be authorised for issue by the Security Council of the United Nations. In July 2008, the Vice Chief of the Defence Force wrote to the United Nations Headquarters Military Adviser, Lieutenant General Chikadibia Obiakor, requesting that he, as the delegate for the award of the United Nations medals, agree to the retrospective award of the UNTAET Medal to the 205 members of the ATST-EM who served during the period 1 March 2001 to 25 July 2005. Defence was passed a response from the United Nations dated 23 December 2008 advising that the United Nations Secretariat has not approved retrospective award of the medal to ATST-EM members. There are no further avenues available to Defence to influence the award of the UNTAET Medal to ATST-EM members, although individuals may apply to the United Nations for reconsideration of their specific circumstance. Visas (Question No. 773) Mr Pyne asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 4 June 2009: In respect of the Government’s changes to the 457 Visa Program, and its announcement on 15 May 2009 that labour agreements aim to provide a flexible response to the needs of industries experiencing skills shortages: (a) what is the average length of time taken for labour agreements to be approved; (b) how is the process considered to be flexible for those employers who experience skills shortages; and (c) how many 457 visa holders are in South Australia; and of these, how many have indicated they are willing to relocate to remote areas such as Coober Pedy in pursuit of training and employment. (a) The time taken to finalise a labour agreement can vary considerably depending on the complexity of the agreement; the number and type of concessions sought, the quality of the information provided and the response times of the employer. It generally takes around four months to prepare a labour agreement, and they can be finalised in about four weeks follow-
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Combet
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Rudd
theText: I am advised that the answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:ing provision of the required documentation. In exceptional circumstances, it can take up to two years to finalise an agreement. (b) The standard Subclass 457 sponsorship arrangement allows sponsors to nominate only people with occupations that are on an occupation list approved for this program. Labour agreements provide flexibility by allowing employers experiencing skills shortages in other occupations or approved occupations who cannot meet the full requirements for the standard Subclass 457 sponsorship arrangement, to negotiate with the Commonwealth approval to nominate skilled overseas workers. (c) There were 2,950 primary visa holders in South Australia at 30 April 2009. The Department of Immigration and Citizenship does not collect data that would indicate whether a visa holder is willing to relocate to more remote areas in pursuit of training and employment. Visas (Question No. 774) Mr Pyne asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 4 June 2009: In respect of the Government’s changes to the 457 Visa Program, and its announcement on 15 May 2009 that labour agreements aim to provide a flexible response to the needs of industries experiencing skills shortages: (a) have any applications for 457 visas been refused as a result of the changes; if so, how many; (b) why is the scheme not being introduced in 2010; and (c) do transitional arrangements exist to (i) provide employers with time to arrange labour agreements, and (ii) allow 457 visa applications received prior to the changes to be processed in accordance with the requirements under the old program; if not, why not. (a) Since the announcement, there has been one nomination refused as a result of this change. (b) The scheme was introduced as part of the package of reforms to the Subclass 457 visa program. The changes are being rolled out when the legislation and systems changes can be made. This change required minor alterations and could be implemented earlier than some other changes. (c) (i) No. (ii) No. The changed arrangements require all applications not finalised on 15 May 2009 to pursue a labour agreement. Applicants who have an existing application not finalised under standard business sponsorship provisions are invited to withdraw their applications and seek a refund of the fee. The government introduced the changes to ensure that employers using the Subclass 457 visa program to access ASCO 5-7 occupations satisfy obligations on local training and employment. First Home Owners Grant Boost (Question No. 776) Mr Morrison asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 4 June 2009: In respect of her media release of 2 June 2009 relating to the numbers of Australians taking-up the First Home Owners Grant Boost: (1) For each month between 1 October 2008 and 30 April 2009, how many grants were given for (a) new construction ($21,000), and (b) existing homes ($14,000). (2) Can she indicate, for each month between 1 October 2008 and 30 April 2009 and in percentage terms, what proportion of grants delivered by each State and territory government comprise the (a) $21,000 for new constructed housing, and (b) $14,000 for sales of existing housing; if not, why not. (1) The breakdown between the take-up of First Home Owners Boost grants for established housing and for new homes is not publicly available. (2) As the First Home Owners Scheme is a stateand territory-based scheme, publication of the number of recipients of the $7,000 First Home Owners Scheme grant is a matter for the States and Territories. Child Care (Question No. 778) Mrs Mirabella asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 15 June 2009: (1) In respect of the now fully operational Child Care Management System (CCMS), for each week for the period 4 May 2009 to 1 June 2009: (a) for how many children did the Government provide the Child Care Benefit (CCB); (b) what was the breakdown, by age, of children in approved care; (c) what was the total cost to the Government of the CCB; (d) what was the total number of reported centre vacancies; and (e) what was the breakdown, by postcode, of centre vacancies. (2) What proportion of total Government spending on the CCB is provided for (a) approved, and (b) registered, care. (3) On average, how many claims for the CCB are made each week for registered care.
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Rudd
theText: I am advised that the answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Swan
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(4) What is the Government’s most recent data on average weekly child care costs. (5) Does she intend to release the results of her department’s November 2008 Survey of Child Care Services; if so, when; if not, why not. Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) (a) (b) & (c) Child Care Benefit (CCB) information captured in the Child Care Management System (CCMS) is not currently available for the period of 4 May 2009 to 1 June 2009. (d) & (e) Aggregated information on reported child care vacancies is not available. (2) In March quarter 2008, approved care accounted for 99.4% of total quarterly CCB expenditure. Registered care accounted for 0.6% of the total quarterly CCB expenditure. (3) On average there are approximately 2,850 families that claimed registered care for approximately 3,260 children per week in March quarter 2008. (4) The most recent data on average weekly child care costs show that in September quarter 2008, the average cost per family was $79.51 after CCB fee reduction. Most families are able to receive 50% of these costs back through the Child Care Tax Rebate, dependent on fulfilling work-study-training requirements. (5) Results from the November 2008 Survey of Child Care Service Providers are available on the DEEWR website: http://www.deewr.gov.au/EarlyChildhood/Resources/Documents/2009SupplementaryTables.pdf Tourism Research Australia (Question No. 781) Mr Ciobo asked the Minister for Tourism, in writing, on 16 June 2009: In respect of his proposed transfer of Tourism Research Australia (TRA) from the auspices of Tourism Australia to his department(1) On what advice did he make the decision to transfer TRA. (2) On what date did he advise (a) his department, and (b) Tourism Australia, of his intention to transfer TRA. (3) On what date will the transfer occur. (4) As at 16 June 2009, how many staff were employed by TRA. (5) Does he foresee a reduction in the number of staff employed by (a) TRA, and (b) Tourism Australia, as a result of the transfer; if so, how many staff of (a) and (b) will lose their jobs. (6) What appropriations have been allocated for the cost of the transfer. (7) Did he ever rescind his direction to transfer TRA; if so, on what date and how. Mr Martin Ferguson-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) My decision to transfer TRA was made on the basis of a range of advice, including feedback from industry. (2) I communicated my intention to the Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism on 25 February 2009. I advised the TA Chair, Rick Allert AO on 29 April 2009. (3) The intention is to have the transfer take effect as soon as practicable. (4) 21. (5) No. (6) There is no additional appropriation required to effect the transfer. (7) I have not issued a direction to transfer TRA. Defence: Evans Head Aerodrome (Question No. 785) Mr Baldwin asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 June 2009: (1) What is the total monetary value of work associated with the decontamination of land at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site. (2) Did the department have any agreement, financial or otherwise, with Richmond Valley Council concerning the decontamination of land at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site; if so, what did the agreement include. (3) Did Richmond Valley Council contribute to the cost of decontaminating land at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site; if so, what sum of money did it contribute. (4) On what date did the decontamination work at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site begin; what stage is it currently at; and by what date is it due for completion. (5) Does the department have any remaining (a) financial, and (b) land title, interests at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site; if so, what are they. (6) On what date was the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site given to the Richmond Valley Council. (7) Does the department retain any rights in respect of the use of the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site; if so, what do these rights entail. (8) What were the original boundaries of the Evans Head Memorial Airfield during World War II. tion: (1) Responsibility for the package of remediation works being undertaken at Evans Head Aerodrome is the responsibility of the Richmond Valley Council. Defence has agreed to assist Council with part of the remediation costs associated with this site to a limit of $1.8 million. (2) Yes. Defence has an agreement with the Richmond Valley Council to contribute $1.8million toward the costs for remediation of the land set aside for an Aged Care Facility. (3) Yes. Richmond Valley Council has committed to fund remediation work at the Aged Care Facility site. Tenders for the work have not yet been called so the cost is not known at this stage. (4) Remediation of the Aged Care Facility site is not due to commence until February 2010. The work is expected to be completed by the end of June 2010. (5) (a) and (b) No. (6) In 1992 ownership of the Aerodrome passed from the then Commonwealth Department of Transport to Richmond River Shire Council (now Richmond Valley Council) under an Airport Local Ownership Plan agreement. (7) No. (8) Richmond Valley Council has advised Defence that to the best of its knowledge, the boundaries of the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome during World War II are described in Lot2 Deposited Plan 214941 dating from 1962. Royal Australian Air Force: Learmonth Base (Question No. 791) Mr Haase asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 23 June 2009: In respect of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Learmonth Base, Western Australia: (a) will an increase in commercial passenger air movement affect RAAF operations; (b) on what date will the current lease arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Shire of Exmouth expire; and (c) what are the critical issues determining an extension or renewal of this lease. tion: (a) A modest increase in the number of civil flights (i.e. a few per day) at RAAF Learmonth would have minimal effect on the Air Force’s operations. (b) The Exmouth Shire was granted a 30 year lease that commenced on 8 March 1993 and expires on 7 March 2023. (c) The current lease is not compliant with the Airports Act 1996 and will not be extended. If the Shire of Exmouth require a lease beyond 2023, a new compliant lease will be required. The lease will also need to address issues associated with the use of Defence infrastructure such as runway usage and the management of aircraft operations. Natural Gas (Question No. 793) Mr Tuckey asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, in writing, on the 23 June 2009: (1) On average, how much (a) natural gas based energy is consumed per calendar year in compressing natural gas so it can travel throughout the Australian domestic natural gas pipeline network, and (b) Carbon Dioxide (CO2) emissions are produced in part (a). (2) What advice has he received on how these CO2 emissions might be reduced other than by increasing the price of natural gas for consumers. Mr Martin Ferguson-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) The Australian pipeline network includes high pressure transmission and low pressure distribution components. The National Inventory Team, part of the Department of Climate Change, compiles emissions data for the purposes of producing the National Greenhouse Accounts. As part of this, it estimates emissions and fuel use separately for high pressure gas transmission and low pressure gas distribution networks. It advised that in 2006-07, the energy use in high pressure natural gas transmission totalled 17 PJ (resulting in 858 kilotonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions). The additional energy use in national gas production and low pressure distribution totalled 6 PJ (resulting in 320 kilotonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions). While the latter figure is not disaggregated, approximately two-thirds (4 PJ) is used in gas distribution. (2) The Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism has not provided any advice to Minister Ferguson on how these emissions might be reduced.

title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Combet
theText: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s quesAusTender Contract Notices (Question No. 799) Dr Southcott asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 25 June 2009: In respect of reposted AusTender Contract Notices CN187855 to CN189059(1) What is the: (a) original AusTender Contract Notice identification number of each, (b) original date each contract was posted on the AusTender website, and (c) contract period for each contract. (2) Was each original posting completed within six weeks of her department entering into the contract; if not, why not, and what are the names of the contract suppliers. Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: Attachment A is provided in response to question 1 (a), (b) and (c). Not all original postings were published within six weeks of the contract start date due to inconsistency of practices in the former DEST and DEWR and the financial and reporting system capabilities – issues which have now been addressed. The names of contract vendors for contracts that were published outside the CPG guidelines are at Attachment B. Attachment A: Listing of Austender records CN187855 to CN189059 is available from the House of Representatives Table Office. Attachment B: Listing of Austender records published after six weeks after engagement is available from the House of Representatives Table Office. AusTender Contract Notices (Question No. 800) Dr Southcott asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 25 June 2009: Have all AusTender Contract Notices posted by her department since 25 November 2007 been reposted on the AusTender website; if not, what are the Contract Notice identification numbers of those that (a) have, and (b) have not, been reposted on the AusTender website. Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: Attachment A is provided in response to the question part (a) and Attachment B is provided in response to part (b) of the question. Attachment A: Listing of republished Austender records is available from the House of Representatives Table Office. Attachment B: Listing of Austender records not republished is available from the House of Representatives Table Office. Disability Employment Services and Employer Incentives Scheme (Question No. 801) Dr Southcott asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Participation, in writing, on 25 June 2009: Can the Minister indicate what the Key Performance Indicators for the Disability Employment Services and Employer Incentives Scheme 2010–12 contract will be? Ms Gillard-The Minister for Employment Participation has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) will form the basis for measuring Disability Employment Services providers’ performance in the categories of efficiency, effectiveness and quality. Proposed KPIs were detailed in the Exposure Draft Of The New Disability Employment Services and Employer Incentives Scheme 2010–2012 Purchasing Arrangements, published on 20 May 2009. The finalised KPIs will be published in the Request for Tender that is scheduled for release in August 2009. Disability Employment Services and Employer Incentives Scheme (Question No. 802) Dr Southcott asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Participation, in writing on 25 June 2009: In respect of the Disability Employment Services and Employer Incentives Scheme 2010–12, what is the key date for (a) the Invitation to Treat, (b) issuing the Request for Tender, (c) the close of tender, and (d) the announcement of successful tenderers. Ms Gillard-The Minister for Employment Participation has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: The exact timing of these events will be announced following the consideration of comments on the Invitation to Treat Discussion Paper, and the Exposure Draft Of The New Disability Employment Services And Employer Incentives Scheme 2010– 2012 Purchasing Arrangements, which were publicly released in May 2009. However, the Invitation to Treat is expected to be completed prior to issue of the Request for Tender in August 2009. Tenders would close around six weeks after issuing of the Request for Tender with the subsequent announcement of successful tenderers scheduled for December 2009. Automotive Industry Training (Question No. 803) Dr Southcott asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 25 June 2009: How widespread was her consultation on the decision to move all automotive industry training to the Manufacturing Skills Association? Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: The consultation process for the decision to move automotive industry training advisory arrangements to Manufacturing Skills Australia was widespread and included peak organisations across both the automotive manufacturing sector and the retail, service and repair sector. Education, Employment and Workplace Relations: Training Costs (Question No. 804) Dr Southcott asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009: What is the expected cost of offering Certificate IV in Government to all of her department’s graduate intake in 2009? Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: A total of 70 graduates from the 2009 intake are currently undertaking the Certificate IV in Government. The expected cost of offering the Certificate IV in Government to the participating graduates is approximately $132,000. Trade Training Centres in Schools (Question No. 805) Dr Southcott asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009: How many tenders were received by her department for the provision of the assessment of applications for funding under the Trade Training Centres in Schools Program? Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: The Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations received 16 compliant tenders for the provision of the assessment of applications for funding under the Trade Training Centres in Schools Program. Second Sydney Airport (Question No. 814) Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 25 June 2009: In respect of the Government’s Aviation Green Paper released in December 2008 and his associated media release of 19 June 2009: (a) has he commenced a site investigation process for a second Sydney airport, in conjunction with the New South Wales Government; (b) given that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) National Platform specifically rules out a second Sydney airport from being developed within the Sydney Basin, and the consultation draft National Platform to be considered at the 2009 ALP National Conference has removed this requirement, will the Government still consider building a second airport within the Sydney Basin; and (c) in respect of aviation policy, what is the Government’s interpretation of the Sydney Basin. The Federal Government has invited the NSW Government to participate in a joint study to assess options, identify potential sites and evaluate investment strategies for delivering additional airport capacity for Sydney. The final terms of reference for the joint study will be released later this year as part of the National Aviation White Paper. Until the findings of the joint study are delivered, the Australian Government is not going to speculate on possible sites for a second Sydney airport. Literacy Levels (Question No. 815) Mr Pyne asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009: (1) What evidence is there to justify claims that there are poor literacy levels among Australian school children? (2) Where is Australia placed on the most recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development comparison on the national literacy levels? Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) What evidence is there to justify claims that there are poor literacy levels among Australian school children? In 2008, the National Assessment Program– Literacy and Numeracy (NAPLAN) commenced in Australian schools. The
title: Questions In Writing

speaker: Mr Albanese
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:fication of those students who have not achieved the minimum national standard for their year level and, who need further help to achieve the skills they require to continue in schooling. The data from the NAPLAN test results gives schools and systems the ability to compare their students’ achievements against national standards and with student achievement in other states and territories. It also allows the monitoring of progress over time. Results from the 2008 NAPLAN tests indicate that at the national level, across the literacy domains and year levels, on average about 80 per cent of students are above the national minimum standard, about 13 per cent are achieving at the national minimum standard and about 7 cent are below the national minimum standard. For Indigenous students at the national level, across the literacy domains and year levels, on average about 44 per cent of Indigenous students are above the national minimum standard, about 23 per cent are achieving at the national minimum standard and about 33 per cent are below the national minimum standard. The results for all year levels and domains can be found in the 2008 National Report at http://www.naplan.edu.au/. (2) Where is Australia placed on the most recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development comparison on national literacy levels? 57 countries participated in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) in 2006 and the results were released in December 2007. Australia’s mean score for reading literacy in PISA 2006 was 513 points, above the OECD average of 492 points. This represented a statistically significant decline from Australia’s mean score in PISA 2003 of 525 points. Australia was significantly outperformed by five countries in PISA 2006: Korea (556), Finland (547), Hong Kong-China (536), Canada (527) and New Zealand (521). Australia performed at a level with no statistically significant difference or not significantly different to Ireland, Liechtenstein, Poland, Sweden and the Netherlands and outperformed all other participating countries. Australia was outperformed by only two countries, Finland and Korea, in PISA 2003. Figure: Pisa 2006 – Student Achievement by Country (Countries are listed by descending order of mean score) Countries achieving significantly higher than Australia Korea (556) (a) Finland (a) Hong-Kong China* (a) Canada (a) New Zealand (a) Countries with no significant difference from Australia Ireland (a) Liechtenstein* (a) Poland (a) Sweden (a) Netherlands (a) Countries achieving significantly lower than Australia Belgium (a) Estonia* (a) Switzerland (a) Japan (b) Chinese Taipei* (b) United Kingdom (b) Germany (b) Denmark (b) Slovenia*(1) (a) Macao-China* (b) OECD average (492) (b) Austria (b) France (b) Iceland (c) Norway (c) Czech Republic (c) Hungary (c) Latvia* (c) Luxembourg (c) Croatia* (c) Portugal (c) Lithuania* (c) Italy (c) Slovak Republic (c) Spain (c) Greece (c) Turkey (c) Chile* (c) Russian Federation* (c) Israel* (c) Thailand* (c) Uruguay* (c) Mexico (c) 13 remaining countries(2), (3) (c) Notes: * Indicates non-OECD country. (1) While Japan had a higher mean score (498) than Slovenia (494), once standard errors are taken into account, Slovenia performed above the OECD average (2) The remaining 13 countries are all non-OECD (partner) countries (3) Reading results for the United States were invalidated by a technical error and are not included. (a) Countries with mean scores significantly above the OECD average (b) Countries with mean scores not significantly different from the OECD average (c) Countries with mean scores significantly below the OECD average Building the Education Revolution Program (Question No. 817) Mr Pyne asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009: In respect of the Building the Education Revolution Program: (a) have any schools with transient enrolments, such as hospital schools, been provided with funding under the program; if not, why not; and (b) are schools with transient enrolments eligible for any other capital grants under other programs; if so, what are the details. Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (a) Funding under the Building the Education Revolution (BER) program is allocated based on full time enrolments at schools. As the students at schools with transient student populations are enrolled at other schools, funding has been provided to those other schools for those students, who are expected to return to their local school and so benefit from the funding. As such, no BER funding is available for schools with transient student populations. (b) The Local Schools Working Together Program is aimed at partnerships to build shared educational facilities. The preferred partnership is between a government and non-government school but it may include a partnership within the educational sector along with a third party. Under this arrangement a school with a transient student population could be a partner with another school eligible to receive recurrent funding under the Schools Assistance Act 2008. Schools: Funding (Question No. 818) Mr Pyne asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009: (1) What sum of money was provided to (a) government, and (b) non-government, schools in every electoral division for the 2007-08 and 2008-09 financial years. (2) What was the (a) expenditure on, (b) location of, and (c) purpose of, each grant in part (1). Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) The government school detail requested in the question is not collected by the Department and is not available. The nongovernment data is not easily compiled and responding to this question would be an unreasonable diversion of the department’s resources. (2) Grant information for General Recurrent Grants (non-government schools only), Capital Grants and Investing in our Schools Program is published in the Green Report annually on a calendar year basis. The latest report is in respect of 2007 funding. Other grants to schools are published on the Department’s websites. Building the Education Revolution Program (Question No. 819) Mr Pyne asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009: In respect of the Building the Education Revolution program: (a) what action does her department take to resolve formal complaints; and (b) are there any complaint operating procedures and guidelines for the program; if so, what are the details; if not, why not. Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (a) Formal complaints about the Building the Education Revolution Program (BER) are received through an email inbox set up for the National BER Coordinator. Every complaint received by the BER Taskforce is investigated by Departmental officers. Replies are sent, wherever possible, within 24 hours. (b) The complaint operating procedures and guidelines for the BER make provision for responses to be provided to all complaints. Once complaints are received, they are registered and the National Coordinator is notified. The complaint is investigated by Departmental officers in consultation with the relevant state/territory education authority or Block Grant Authority and a response is prepared. Distance Education (Question No. 820) Mr Pyne asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009: Is the Government committed to funding distance education; if so, what are the full details of its commitment to public distance education providers. Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: The Australian Government believes that every parent has the right to choose an education that best suits the needs of their child, irrespective of their religious beliefs. I acknowledge that regular schools are not available or may not be suitable for all children and therefore distance education fulfils a need. The Government provides funding for distance education students that are using registered distance education facilities which are part of a registered non-government school. The Australian Government provides funding for students educated at government schools under the National Education Agreement. It is each state and territory’s responsibility to determine its priorities in the provision of education, including distance education. Higher Education (Question No. 821) Mr Pyne asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009: (1) For the calendar years 2006, 2007, 2008, and 2009: (a) what was the total number of school leavers enrolled in (i) Vocational Education and Training (VET), and (ii) university; and (b) what percentage of all school leavers enrolled in (i) VET, and (ii) university. (2) What sum was allocated in the 2009-10 Budget to (a) VET providers, including TAFE’s, and (b) universities? Ms Gillard-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Mr Pyne’s question is specific to ‘school leavers’. There is not a national administrative data collection of school leaver numbers, and hence percentages can not be derived as requested. However the Australian Bureau of Statistics’ annual ‘Survey of Education and Work’ publishes estimates of school leavers aged 15 to 24 years, and their study destinations. The survey estimates that there were 302 100 school leavers in 2006, 303 100 in 2007, and 313 600 in 2008. Enrolments at bachelor degree level or above were estimated at 82 600 in 2006, or 27.3 per cent of school leavers, at 83 600 in 2007 (27.6 per cent), and 83 900 in 2008 (26.8 per cent). Enrolments in vocational studies were estimated at 79 200 in 2006, or 26.2 per cent of school leavers, at 82 300 in 2007 (27.2 per cent), and 89 000 in 2008 (28.4 per cent). (2) (a) In the 2009-10 Budget $2 657 482 000 was allocated for funding for training to VET Providers, including TAFE’s. This includes funding provided to states and territories to fund their VET training systems through the Inter Government Agreement on Federal Financial Relations and the VET infrastructure component of the Education Infrastructure Fund. In prior years, under the Skilling Australia’s Workforce Act 2005 and the 2005-2008 Commonwealth-State Agreement for Skilling Australia’s Workforce, States and Territories were required to contribute base recurrent funding on a 2:1 ratio to Commonwealth government funding, plus match the Commonwealth on additional recurrent funding. All States and Territories met or exceeded this requirement during the period of the Skilling Australia’s Workforce Agreement. Under the new Inter Government Agreement there is no specific requirement in terms of the amount to be contributed by States and Territories. (b) In the 2009-10 Budget $6 350 955 000 was allocated for 2009-10 for the higher education sector (including universities and other eligible bodies) through the Education, Employment and Workplace Relations portfolio. This excludes funding to universities through the Innovation, Industry, Science and Research portfolio. This also excludes funding allocated for Commonwealth Scholarships administered by higher education providers, Higher Education Loan Program assistance for students and Education Investment Fund VET projects. Private Health Insurance (Question No. 827) Mr Dutton asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009: (1) As at 31 March 2009, how many (a) people were covered by private health insurance policies provided by an employer; and (b) businesses provided Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership for their employees. (2) Did his department or any other agency model the effect of the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy on businesses which provide Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership to employees (1) The number of employer-provided private health insurance policies is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits. (2) The effect of the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy on businesses which provide Fringe Benefits Taxliable private health insurance membership to employees was not modelled due to information on the number and incomes of such employees not being available. Private Health Insurance (Question No. 828) Mr Dutton asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009: (1) Is his department able to estimate the additional annual increase in private health premium liabilities for businesses which provide Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership for their employees from 1 July 2010, due to the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy; if so, what is the quantum of those liabilities. The increase in private health insurance premium liabilities for business cannot be quantified, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits. Private Health Insurance (Question No. 829) Mr Dutton asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009: Is his department able to estimate the additional annual Fringe Benefits Tax liabilities to businesses which provide Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership for employees from 1 July 2010 due to the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy; if so, what is the quantum of those liabilities. The additional fringe benefit tax liability for businesses with employer-provided private health insurance policies is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits. Private Health Insurance (Question No. 830) Mr Dutton asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009: Is his department able to estimate how many businesses will no longer provide Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership for their employees from 1 July 2010 as a result of the increase in premium costs associated with the introduction of the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy; if so, how many. The number of businesses who no longer provide private health insurance policies as a result of the policy is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits.

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Private Health Insurance (Question No. 831) Mr Dutton asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009: Is his department able to estimate how many people will no longer have their private health insurance membership provided by an employer from 1 July 2010 as a result of the introduction of the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy; if so, how many. The number of people who no longer have employer-provided private health insurance policies as a result of the policy is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits. Private Health Insurance (Question No. 832) Mr Dutton asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009: What sum of Fringe Benefits Tax revenue from businesses which provide private health insurance membership to employees did the Government receive in 2007-08. The fringe benefits tax revenue collected due to employer-provided private health insurance is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits. Private Health Insurance (Question No. 833) Mr Dutton asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009: What sum of Fringe Benefits Tax revenue from businesses which provide private health insurance membership to employees does the Government expect to receive in the 2008-09 and 2009-10 financial years. The fringe benefits tax revenue collected due to employer-provided private health insurance is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits. Private Health Insurance (Question No. 834) Mr Dutton asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009: What sum of Fringe Benefits Tax revenue does the Government expect to forfeit in the 2010-11 financial year as a result of businesses reducing their provision of private health insurance membership to employees. The change in fringe benefits tax revenue collected in the 2010-11 financial year due to any changes in the provision of employer-provided private health insurance is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits. Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts: Staffing (Question No. 839) Mr Hunt asked the Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts, in writing, on 25 June 2009: In respect of his Ministerial staff: (1) What is the complete listing of staff located in his offices in (a) Sydney, and (b) and any other locations. (2) What are the details of their (a) classification, (b) salary, and (c) when they commenced working with him. (3) What are the details concerning staff who have left his employment, including when. The information below was provided by the Department of Finance and Deregulation, as at 25 June 2009. Classifications and salary ranges only are provided so as not to identify personal information of individual employees.
